page.title: 17Pilgrims' Way & St.Martha's
page.content:
It is not known for certain that pilgrims walked along this path but it is still called the Pilgrims' Way. It was an important communications route from iron age times. The line of the Pilgrims' Way may be easily followed along the banks of the River Wey, up onto the downs, through the Chantry woods and straight on to St. Martha's Church.
The church was built between 1100 and 1170. It took a long time to build because chalk had to be brought from Newland's Corner. Water for the building materials also had to be transported uphill because there are no streams on the downs. Many pilgrims visited the church en route to Canterbury.
